sentence: When a stock reacts illogically to an earnings release and commentators are left scrambling for a reason why, it usually represents an opportunity for investors.
Why waste time and effort coming up with a reason why it moved?
Seemingly illogical moves happen all the time in the stock market, but over time fundamentals win.
If something jumps sharply on what looks like a mediocre quarter and there is no major announcement or significantly altered guidance, then it is usually right to trade in the opposite direction.
That is the case today with Salesforce.com (CRM).
I have nothing against Salesforce.
I have used their product and am fully aware of how much value it adds to businesses, large or small.
They are a remarkable growth story that has plenty of room to continue.
The problem is simply one of valuation.
To understand why, you have to understand, or maybe remind yourself, what a forward P/E actually is.
When we use a metric frequently it becomes easy to see it only as a number and forget how that number is arrived at.
CRM’s forward P/E of around 350 after yesterday’s reaction to earnings, for example, is high compared to the average.
We know that, but for a growth company in the tech space it is not seen as excessive by many investors.
When we break down the calculation of forward P/E, however, and consider yesterday’s numbers in light of that, it begins to look way over the top.
Forward P/E is arrived at by dividing the price by share by the next twelve months anticipated earnings.
The calculation is simple enough, but it is the “forward” part of that equation that is of interest.
Of course, we cannot know next year’s earnings, so we use an average of Wall Street analysts’ estimates.
Those estimates have, by definition, expected growth baked into them.
That can be difficult for analysts when dealing with a company growing as rapidly as Salesforce.
How do you factor in consistent 30 percent growth without getting carried away?
The tendency is usually to assume that growth will slow and underestimate future revenue and profit.
In the past that has been the case with CRM, but the Street has caught up.
If anything analysts currently err on the side of overestimating CRM’s growth, or at least their ability and desire to use that growth to turn a profit.
That is why the company had missed EPS expectations in the last three quarters.
They are still growing rapidly and are beginning to retain some of that revenue, but expectations have caught up with growth and actual profit is still falling short.
So, fast forward to yesterday when Salesforce announces results that are almost exactly in line with Street expectations.
That implies that the analysts are getting the hang of it.
They have a handle on roughly how fast CRM will grow and how much will be ploughed back into growing some more.
At that point it becomes hard, if not impossible, for Salesforce to justify a 350 forward P/E.

The average forward P/E for the S&P 500 is approximately 20, which means that to justify a multiple of 350 Salesforce must not just grow at a significantly faster rate than other companies, but actually beat estimates by 17.5 times.
That will be tough now that the evidence suggests that those estimates have caught up with the company’s impressive growth rate.

The most common reason for yesterday’s huge positive reaction to what looked, on the surface, to be pretty average results was the increased possibility of future revenues as deferred payments and bookings were up.
The only problem with that is that the company’s actual guidance was a little light.
That suggests that management, who after all are best placed to quantify that benefit, aren’t convinced that it will translate to growth in either earnings or revenue much above current expectations.
It looks more like a classic case of something reacting more to a general trend than to specific results.
Business to business tech is hot and rapid growth is in short supply, so CRM was going up almost whatever happened short of a disastrous miss.
Momentum is powerful and we may see a day or two more of gains based on that, but without supporting evidence momentum can reverse quickly.
What the actual numbers released yesterday indicate is that expectations have caught up with the company and are probably about to overtake reality.
That means that a momentum reversal cannot be far away.
It is time for the smart investor to sell.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
